docs.lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Katrina, "refugee" became a dirty word. But the refugee, it seems, has it all over the evacuee.

docs.lead_paragraph: Subsidized child care would ease the burden on low-income working mothers, but they also need health insurance and more time and income to care for their families.

byline.original: By BETSY GOTBAUM    and NANCY RANKIN

docs.lead_paragraph: Dana Lynne Karash, the daughter of Jacquelyn and Ronald Karash of Oklahoma City, and Abigail Marie Rowe, a daughter of Valerie Rowe and Dr. John W. Rowe of New York, affirmed their partnership yesterday afternoon. Helen Hess, a friend of the couple, led a commitment ceremony at the Adirondack Rock and River, a bed and breakfast in Keene, N.Y.

headline.print_headline: Richest Kids on the Block Find That Money May Talk, But Money Can't Dance

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a visual artist with an Ivy League education (Penn '94), I thought ''Money Changes Everything'' (May 7) provided an interesting (and relevant) read. I imagine I am describing the financial states of many of my colleagues when I confess that I have no savings; I carry monstrous student loans; and I sometimes overdraw my checking account to pay for my health insurance. Do I feel shame? Sometimes. Is it warranted? I hope not.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Wroblewski letter on May 7 article Money Changes Everything says that as visual artist her self-worth is not in dollars

docs.lead_paragraph: The board of the Nassau Health Care Corporation has dismissed its president and chief executive, Daniel A. Kane, with 18 months left on his contract because of what it called a ''lack of uniform support on the part of Nassau County stakeholders.'' No successor was named.

headline.main: Health Chief Dismissed; Bailout Concerns Cited
